page.title: 12BRIEF HISTORY CURY/GUNWALLOE
page.content: The area was first inhabited by Celts about 700 B.C. Roman occupation followed but had little influence on life in the area. Later monks and missionaries from Ireland and Breton entered the area. The Lizard Peninsula became a refuge for leprosy victims of the Crusades.(The word Lizard possible coming from the word'Lazare'disease). Sir Roger Carminoe also returned from the Crusades having fought with Prince Edward in 1270.The present Carminoe Farm is all that remains of the former Manor with its Manorial/Feudal system which presided over the area for centuries.The words Cury and Gunwalloe probably derive from the Cornish Language meaning 'Boundary' and 'Open land'. The area was also famous for smugglers and wreckers. A famous character being one Henry Cuttance of Gunwalloe and innkeeper of Halzephron.
